pros: Very fun coworkers, was fun working with the kids
cons: The system is very hierarchical, and the higher-ups clearly didn't care about their employees very much. We seemed very expendable. A lot of my coworkers were put on suspension for complaining about our supervisor.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Treated well and with good health insurance. Not technically a full time employee due to the student title, though seemingly treated as an employee
cons: Requires plenty of work to get degree while fulfilling requirements of university to be considered an employee. No dental

review_title: It has been fun and exciting.
pros: There are many good scientists that works at Duke and there is a collaborative atmosphere all around.  The people around you are usually very helpful.
cons: Advising can be non existant some times.  Graduate studies can take a long time.  You need to be very self motivated or you might be there a long time.

review_title: Not too good not too bad
pros: Living expense is low. Some programs are excellent. The campus is great. Student health insurance coverage is generous. It is a good place to relax.
cons:
Duke is kind of in the middle of nowhere, and I don't like this fact.
The chemistry program here is very weak, which is absolutely not proportional to the overall reputation of Duke.

pros: Great working environment, benefits, and support staff. I worked on the research side, and Duke definitely tries to provide everything you need for a successful lab.
cons: Very rare difficulties with academic bureaucracy. Additionally the payroll department can be very inflexible and occasionally makes mistakes that they are unable to fix in a timely manner.

job_title: Ph D Candidate in Durham, NC
pros: Durham is a burgeoning southern town with enough going on to keep you busy, but not too much to be a distraction from Ph.D. work.  Lots of great eateries.  The University has a larger graduate and professional student population, so there is always something going on, not just basketball. ;-)
cons: The town is "developing" which is code for gentrification.

review_title: Getting paid to do the work I love
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Exciting research, beautiful campus, healthcare benefits, flexible hours
cons: Getting a PhD in computer science generally pays less than half as well as working in industry. You have to want to do research for it to be worthwhile. Work/life balance is pretty imbalanced, but that's normal for programming and research.

pros:
The best platform to hone your skills.
Good platform to network and meet new people.
Excellent faculty.
Alumni network is out of this world.
Courses for my field are excellent. May differ for different majors.
cons: The only con is the fact that it is situated in NC, and the climate change here is drastic. Other than that no con about the institution as such.

pros: Rewarding working with great kids and fellow staff.  Extremely fun experience. Geared towards the kinds of people who attended or likely would have attended high achieving academic camp; if this is your bag, you will love it.
cons: Hard work for relatively low compensation (however room and board are provided); may be viewed by some as socially "niche" (See above).

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros:
- Flexible hours
- Friendly colleagues
- Fun and interesting work
cons: The only con I can say is that for some undergrads, the pay can feel a bit stingy, and your bosses may expect a lot from you. You will probably remain engaged, but the payoff may sometimes not feel worth it unless you have other goals in mind.

pros:
Employee health plan
Employee discounts locally and nationally
Discounted tickets to events
Many training opportunities
cons: movement to monthly/salaried position is difficult for hourly staff who seek growth; stagnant merit increases - costs go up and multi year no increase has existing employees less competitive with compensation as new employees. 'have to leave and come back' to get any compensation review.

review_title: Great benefit for grad students, inexpensive area
pros: Durham is cheap, allowing you to live comfortably with you grad stipend. Professors are generally helpful
cons: The area may be unsafe. Thus, a car is pretty much a necessity since people tend to live far away from the campus. But if you mostly spend time at school then it's not such a big problem

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Flexible hours, autonomy, freedom to pursue what interests me
cons: Low pay, long hours are required to finish the degree program in a reasonable period of time, the work follows you home, high stress, little respect for graduate students from the university as a whole and figures of authority.

pros:
Incredible opportunities to meet world-class people
Your voice is heard
Opportunity for growth
Competitive environment
Not cutthroat like Ivy league universities
cons:
You must really work hard to stand out
Long hours studying
Social life off campus is not great

review_title: Grad School Teaching Assistants are overworked and underpaid

cons: outside perks---terrible parking, car gets towed during basketball games, snobby undergrads and professors

pros: Duke is a fun campus with tons of jobs available for undergraduate students. You will have a lot of competition for jobs, but if you search, there will be no issue.
cons: The competition for jobs is the toughest part. When there are fantastic opportunities available, students across campus jump at their chance and are tough to beat out.

review_title: Duke has been an okay place to start a career. It's one of the most accredited hospitals in the country.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Durham, NC

cons: As a private hospital, we don't see a lot of raises and/or bonuses

pros: fun work environment and managers willing to help when understaffed. Good pay and good benefits.

review_title: Variety of organization, Atmosphere is totally depends on departments

cons: If you are working with non responsible PI, or with someone (PI or staff) has complicated political relationships, the situation can be really bad.

review_title: Duke University provides great core facilities, great collegial atmosphere, and top notch research opportunities.

job_title: Visiting Teaching Fellow in Durham, NC

pros: The atmosphere for employees is pretty fantastic.  They do a great job of maintaining a full staff so that we're not overworked and the students are helpful and a pleasure to work with.
cons: There should be parking dedicated for the staff, or at the very least, we should get a discount on parking passes.

pros:
Pension offered
Advancement opportunities
Training opportunities
Education credit for yourself and child
Good PTO and holiday time
Beautiful campus
cons:
Pay for parking, no way around it unless you live close enough to walk or bike ride
Low pay

review_title: Great university, inflated egos, some bad professionals
pros: Good place to work and live . Nice facilities. Good academic environment . Campus well taken care  . Good Benefit and health insurance plans.
cons: Unethical professionals . Poor people management . Politicized environment at some departments . Lack of support. Lots of leg pulling

pros: Good benefits, access to gym, health, dental, eye, insurance, 403(b) retirement, Duke Credit Union access, employee discounts with phone carriers and other vendors, online database learning subscription, extensive library database access. Supervision and management is flexible and willing to help you develop.
cons: Not many. I wish I was paid more, but who doesn't want more money?

pros: Durham is a quiet town so it allows us to concentrate on study. Furthermore, there are so many tourist attractions at the town

pros:
Good benefit options and solid resources, such as Duke's collection of libraries.

Duke has a great postdoctoral association that organizes events---both professional and social.  The association is the biggest and most helpful service the university provides to me.

job_title: Duke Tip Residential Counselor in Durham, NC

cons: Hours are kinda weird. But its basically like living in college so its completely fine. Pay is not that great, but they provide food and housing and the job is so much fun.

review_title: Good environment but limited salaries and advancement
job_title: Senior IT Analyst in Durham, NC

review_title: Good start for my career but ending not so good
pros: Advancement opportunities, good benefits, pay has been good over time.
cons: Everything is not always what it seems, not a trusting environment in my department.

pros: Friendly coworkers, flexible hours, lots of food

review_title: Great place to do a PhD

cons: It's hard to list a number of specific cons for this job, although the primary con will be the slow pace of research when using animal models.

pros: Duke has the most beautiful campus I have ever seen. The employees are highly qualified and very professional. Everyone is organized and responsive.

review_title: Great place to work if you can find the right fit

pros:
Mostly young crowd
